fields.description: Full product name including brand and variant. Extract the complete name as displayed on the page.
Brand or producer name. This is typically the main company or distillery name.
Product description providing an overview of the product, its characteristics, and background.
examples: A classic Islay single malt with smoky, peaty flavors...
This award-winning bourbon is crafted from...

fields.description: Alcohol percentage (0-80). Look for: ABV, Alcohol by Volume, Alcohol Content, Alc./Vol., Alc/Vol, Vol%, % Vol, % vol. For Proof (US), divide by 2 (e.g., 80 proof = 40% ABV). Also look for: Alkoholgehalt (German), Titre alcoometrique (French).
Age statement of the product. Extract as shown (e.g., '12', '18 Year Old', 'NAS' for No Age Statement).

Bottle volume in milliliters. CONVERSION: 75cl=750ml, 70cl=700ml, 1L=1000ml, 50cl=500ml, 35cl=350ml. US sizes: 750ml standard, 1L, 375ml (half bottle). Convert fl oz: multiply by 29.57. Common sizes: 50ml (miniature), 200ml, 350ml, 500ml, 700ml (EU standard), 750ml (US standard), 1000ml (1L), 1750ml.
Country of origin. Where the product was produced or distilled.
Production region within the country. For whiskey: Speyside, Islay, Kentucky, etc. For port: Douro Valley.
Sub-category of the product. For whiskey: Bourbon, Scotch Single Malt, Rye, etc. For port: Ruby, Tawny, Vintage, etc.
Global Trade Item Number (barcode) for exact product matching. Look for EAN, UPC, or GTIN.

Description of the product's color and appearance. LOOK FOR: sections labeled 'Color', 'Colour', 'Appearance', 'Eye', 'Visual'. Common color terms: pale gold, amber, copper, mahogany, deep amber, golden honey, rich brown, ruby red, tawny. This field enables derivation of color_intensity.
examples: Pale straw with hints of gold

fields.description: Color intensity rating on a scale of 1-10. 1=very pale, 10=very dark. DERIVE FROM color_description: pale/light=2-3, golden=4-5, amber=5-6, deep amber=6-7, copper/mahogany=7-8, dark/rich=8-10.
Clarity of the liquid. Look for terms describing transparency.
Viscosity or body of the liquid. Often described by 'legs' or 'tears' in the glass.

Tasting notes describing the aroma/nose of the product. LOOK FOR: sections labeled 'Nose', 'Aroma', 'Bouquet', 'On the nose', 'Aromas', 'Scent'. Extract the full prose description mentioning all aroma notes - this enables derivation of primary_aromas array. Include intensity descriptors (light, strong, bold) and time evolution if mentioned.
examples: Rich honey and vanilla with hints of citrus and oak
Intense peat smoke with maritime notes and seaweed
Opens with marzipan and mocha, developing into charred oak and nougat with hints of chestnuts

fields.description: List of primary aroma notes detected on the nose. IMPORTANT: Extract individual flavor descriptors as separate items in the array. If only prose nose_description is available, parse it to extract individual aroma notes. Common descriptors: vanilla, honey, oak, peat, smoke, citrus, floral, fruit, spice, caramel, chocolate, coffee, leather, tobacco.

Intensity of the primary aromas on a scale of 1-10. DERIVE FROM nose_description: subtle/delicate=3-4, moderate=5-6, pronounced/strong=7-8, powerful/intense=9-10. Look for words like 'subtle', 'intense', 'bold', 'delicate', 'powerful'.

List of secondary or subtle aroma notes that emerge after the primary aromas. IMPORTANT: Extract individual descriptors as separate array items. If only prose nose_description is available, parse it to extract subtle background notes that develop over time.

How the aromas evolve over time as the spirit opens up in the glass. DERIVE FROM nose_description if it mentions progression or time-based changes. Look for: 'opens with', 'develops into', 'after time', 'with air', 'initially', 'later reveals', 'eventually'.
examples: Opens with fruit notes, develops into spice after 10 minutes
Initially smoky, revealing sweetness with air

fields.description: Tasting notes describing the palate/taste. LOOK FOR: sections labeled 'Palate', 'Taste', 'On the palate', 'Flavor', 'Flavour', 'Tasting Notes'. Extract the full prose description mentioning all flavor notes - this enables derivation of palate_flavors array. Include texture descriptors (smooth, oily, creamy) and intensity notes.
examples: Smooth and creamy with notes of caramel, toffee, and gentle spice
Bold and smoky with layers of dark fruit and oak
The sweet toast of American oak with deep notes of butterscotch, toffee, and toasted walnuts

fields.description: List of flavor notes detected on the palate. IMPORTANT: Extract individual taste descriptors as separate array items. If only prose palate_description is available, parse it to extract individual flavor notes. Common descriptors: caramel, toffee, vanilla, honey, oak, spice, pepper, cinnamon, chocolate, coffee, fruit, citrus, nuts. CRITICAL: This field is required for COMPLETE status.

First impression on the palate - the initial taste when the spirit hits the tongue. DERIVE FROM palate_description if it mentions initial impact. Look for: 'opens with', 'initial', 'first', 'attack', 'entrance', 'arrival', 'immediately'.

How flavors develop and change in the middle of the tasting experience. DERIVE FROM palate_description if it mentions mid-palate development. Look for: 'develops', 'mid-palate', 'evolves', 'transitions', 'builds', 'then', 'followed by'.
examples: Develops into rich toffee and oak
Transitions to dark chocolate and espresso notes

fields.description: Overall intensity of flavors on the palate on a scale of 1-10. DERIVE FROM palate_description: light/subtle=3-4, medium/balanced=5-6, full/rich=7-8, intense/powerful=9-10. Look for: 'light', 'delicate', 'bold', 'full-bodied', 'intense', 'powerful', 'robust'.
Complexity rating on a scale of 1-10. How many layers of flavor are present.

Texture and body of the spirit in the mouth. DERIVE FROM palate_description if it mentions texture. Look for: 'oily', 'creamy', 'silky', 'thin', 'velvety', 'chewy', 'waxy', 'smooth', 'thick', 'viscous', 'light-bodied', 'full-bodied', 'rich'.

Tasting notes describing the finish/aftertaste. LOOK FOR: sections labeled 'Finish', 'Aftertaste', 'The finish', 'Lingering notes'. Extract the full prose description mentioning all finish notes - this enables derivation of finish_flavors array. Include length descriptors (short, medium, long, endless) and any lingering flavor notes.
examples: Long and warming with lingering spice and oak
Medium finish with notes of dried fruit and gentle smoke
Medium to long, slightly dry. Oak spices linger with dark caramel and mocha.

fields.description: List of flavor notes detected in the finish/aftertaste. IMPORTANT: Extract individual taste descriptors as separate array items. If only prose finish_description is available, parse it to extract individual flavor notes that linger after swallowing. Common descriptors: oak, spice, vanilla, honey, smoke, pepper, warmth, chocolate, coffee, leather, dried fruit.

Length of the finish on a scale of 1-10. 1=very short, 10=exceptionally long. DERIVE FROM finish_description: short=2-3, medium=4-5, medium-long=6-7, long=7-8, very long/endless=9-10. Look for: 'short', 'medium', 'long', 'lingering', 'endless', 'fades quickly'.

Warmth or alcohol heat on a scale of 1-10. Often correlates with ABV. DERIVE FROM finish_description: gentle/subtle=3-4, warming=5-6, hot/fiery=7-8, intense heat=9-10. Look for: 'warming', 'hot', 'fiery', 'heat', 'burn', 'gentle warmth', 'alcohol bite'.

Dryness on a scale of 1-10. 1=very sweet finish, 10=bone dry finish. DERIVE FROM finish_description: sweet=2-3, off-dry=4-5, dry=6-7, very dry=8-9, bone dry=10. Look for: 'sweet', 'dry', 'tannic', 'astringent', 'drying'.
How the finish evolves and fades over time. DERIVE FROM finish_description if it mentions progression. Look for: 'starts with', 'fades to', 'lingers', 'eventually', 'develops into', 'gives way to'.
examples: Starts spicy, fades to gentle oak
Smoke lingers while fruit notes emerge

fields.description: The very last lingering notes after the finish fades. DERIVE FROM finish_description if it mentions final/lingering notes. Look for: 'lingers', 'final', 'last notes', 'leaves you with', 'hints of', 'subtle'.
Independent bottler name if this is an independent bottling (not official distillery release).

Primary cask types used for maturation. DERIVE FROM maturation_notes. Look for: 'matured in', 'aged in', 'ex-bourbon', 'ex-sherry', 'first-fill', 'refill', 'virgin oak', 'hogshead', 'butt'. Common types: ex-bourbon, ex-sherry, ex-wine, port cask, rum cask, virgin oak.

Cask types used for finishing after primary maturation. DERIVE FROM maturation_notes. Look for: 'finished in', 'cask finish', 'double matured', 'extra maturation'. Common: sherry, port, rum, wine, Sauternes, Madeira casks.

Types of wood used in the casks. DERIVE FROM maturation_notes. Look for: 'American oak', 'European oak', 'Spanish oak', 'French oak', 'Japanese Mizunara', 'virgin oak'. Also: Quercus alba, Quercus robur.

How the casks were treated - charred, toasted, etc. DERIVE FROM maturation_notes. Look for: 'charred', 'toasted', 'heavily charred', 'lightly toasted', 'char level', 'alligator char', 'new charred', 'virgin charred'.
Detailed notes about the maturation process, aging conditions, warehouse type, etc.
examples: Matured for 12 years in ex-bourbon casks then finished in PX sherry butts

fields.description: Overall balance rating on a scale of 1-10. How well the flavors harmonize.
Overall complexity rating on a scale of 1-10. The depth and layers of the experience.
Uniqueness or distinctiveness rating on a scale of 1-10.
Drinkability or accessibility rating on a scale of 1-10. How easy is it to enjoy.
Value for money rating on a scale of 1-10. Quality relative to price.
Recommended experience level for enjoying this product.
How the product is best served or enjoyed.
Recommended food pairings for the product.
Competition awards won by this product. Extract competition name, year, medal level, and category if available.

medal.description: Medal or award level (Gold, Silver, Bronze, Double Gold, Best in Class)

fields.description: Ratings from critics, publications, or users. Extract source, score, scale, and reviewer if available.

reviewer.description: Name of the reviewer if available

date.description: Date of the review if available

fields.description: Price information from retailers. Extract price, currency, retailer name, and availability.

in_stock.description: Whether the product is in stock

fields.description: Product images. Extract URL and image type (bottle, label, lifestyle).

type.description: Image type: bottle, label, lifestyle, detail

fields.description: Name of the distillery where the whiskey was produced.
Type classification of the whiskey.
Grain composition or mash bill of the whiskey.
Whether this is a cask strength (undiluted) release. Look for 'cask strength', 'barrel proof', 'natural strength'.
Whether this is from a single cask (not vatted/married). Look for 'single cask', 'single barrel'.
Cask number for single cask releases.
Year the whiskey was distilled.
Year the whiskey was bottled.
Batch or release number.
Whether the whiskey uses peated malt. Look for 'peated', 'peat', 'smoky'.
Level of peat used.
Phenol parts per million - a measure of peat level. Higher = more smoky.
Whether the whiskey has no added color (E150a). Look for 'natural color', 'no color added', 'no E150a'.
Whether the whiskey is non-chill filtered (NCF). Look for 'non-chill filtered', 'NCF', 'unchillfiltered'.
Port wine style classification. Look for: Ruby, Tawny, White, Rose, LBV (Late Bottled Vintage), Vintage, Colheita, Crusted, Single Quinta, Garrafeira.
Age indication for tawny ports. Look for '10 Year', '20 Year', '30 Year', '40 Year', 'Over 40 Years'.
Year of grape harvest for vintage ports. Also called 'vintage year' or 'declared vintage'.
Year the port was bottled. Important for LBV and Colheita ports.
Grape varieties used in the port. Traditional varieties include Touriga Nacional, Touriga Franca, Tinta Roriz, Tinta Barroca, Tinto Cao.
Name of the quinta (vineyard estate) where the grapes were grown. Look for 'Quinta de...', 'Quinta do...', 'Quinta da...'.
Subregion within the Douro Valley. Baixo Corgo (cooler, lighter wines), Cima Corgo (best vineyards), Douro Superior (hottest, ripest fruit).
Port house or producer name. Major houses include Taylor's, Graham's, Fonseca, Dow's, Cockburn's, Sandeman, Warre's, Croft, Niepoort.
Type of vessel used for aging. Pipes (550L casks) for tawny, large wooden vats or bottles for vintage ports.
Whether decanting is recommended. Vintage ports usually need decanting; tawny and LBV generally don't.
Optimal drinking window for the port. Important for vintage ports which can age for decades.
